subject: RE: [junit] Testing OS specific end-of-lines in the standard out of a program
msgSnippet: It isn t that it is a stupid question.  The thing is to ask questions smartly.  One of the best things to do before asking the question is read the
messageBody:
It isn't that it is a stupid question. The thing is to ask questions
smartly. One of the best things to do before asking the question is
read the documentation, or do some research. Since your questions are
such simple things, I don't really mind offering a "free" answer. If
were something that I thought you should do some research, I would have
said so.

-jason

------------------------------------------------------------------------
------
Jason Rogers Email:
jrogers@...
Software Consultant Direct:
248-204-7180
Great Lakes Technologies Group Main:
248-352-6740
-----Original Message-----
From: Chappell, Simon P [mailto:simon.chappell@...]
Sent: Thursday, November 29, 2001 8:46 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Testing OS specific end-of-lines in the standard
out of a program


It worked. Thank you. I'll try not to ask such a stupid question again!
:-)

>-----Original Message-----
>From: Chappell, Simon P
>Sent: Thursday, November 29, 2001 7:14 AM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: RE: [junit] Testing OS specific end-of-lines in the standard
>out of a program
>
>
>Doh! Should've thought of that! I'll try it and report back.
>
>>-----Original Message-----
>>From: Rogers, Jason [mailto:jrogers@...]
>>Sent: Thursday, November 29, 2001 6:48 AM
>>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>>Subject: RE: [junit] Testing OS specific end-of-lines in the standard
>>out of a program
>>
>>
>>Instead of using literals in the program (\n \r), use the
>>System.getProperty("line.separator") and test against that if you need
>>to test it. Using this and others in the code (i.e.
>>getProperty("file.separator") or File.SEPARATOR, etc.) will greatly
>>reduce the need to "port" to other OS's.
>>
>>-jason
>>
>>----------------------------------------------------------
>>Jason Rogers Email: jrogers@...
>>Software Consultant Direct: 248-204-7180
>>Great Lakes Technologies Group Main: 248-352-6740
>>-----Original Message-----
>>From: Chappell, Simon P [mailto:simon.chappell@...]
>>Sent: Thursday, November 29, 2001 7:39 AM
>>To: JUnit mailing list (E-mail)
>>Subject: [junit] Testing OS specific end-of-lines in the
>>standard out of
>>a program
>>
>>
>>Now that the good folks of this list have assisted me in obtaining the
>>standard out of the java object that I was testing, I have one further
>>question.
>>
>>What is the prevailing best practice for testing the output
>when it has
>>different end-of-line markers from different operating systems? My
>>lovely new tests are failing on Microsoft Windows!
>>
>>I use Linux primarily but also have to deliver software and their unit
>>tests to people using Microsoft Windows and let's not forget Mac OSX.
>>
>>Thank you in advance.
>>
>>Simon
>>
